questions.question: What are neuroendocrine cells in the bronchial mucosa called?
questions.explanation: Kulchitsky cells are neuroendocrine cells found in the bronchial mucosa.

questions.question: In which of the following are the pores of Kohn located?
questions.explanation: Pores of Kohn (alveolar pores) are seen in the alveolar wall.They are the interalveolar connections that permit the passage of bacteria and exudate betweenadjacent alveoli. This plays an important role in the pathogenesis of lobar pneumonia. Duringthe gray hepatization phase, fibrin also spreads through these pores.When the lung is partially deflated, collateral ventilation can also occur to some extent throughthese pores.AlveoliMOLOWAlveolar pores or Pores of kohnOMARROW

questions.question: Which of the following is false about alveolar epithelium?

options.A: Type 1 cells are not involved in surfactant production
options.B: Type 1 cells form the lining epithelium of alveoli
options.C: Type 2 cells are involved in the repair of the epithelium
options.D: Type 2 cells are involved in gaseous exchange

questions.explanation: Type II pneumocytes are not involved in gaseous exchange. They are only involved in repair andsurfactant production.Alveolar epithelium is a continuous layer of two cell types:The following image shows types of cells in the alveoli.Type I pneumocytesFlattened, plate-likeThe lining epithelium of alveoli (covers 95% of the alveolar surface) Gaseous exchangeType II pneumocytesRoundedSynthesize surfactant Repairof the alveolar epitheliumRegeneration of type I cells1070Alveolar cellsAlveolarcells type 2Alveolarcells type 1Capillary

questions.question: Ciliocytophthoria is seen in:
questions.explanation: Ciliocytophthoria refers to the degeneration of ciliated cells. It occurs in viral infections, suchas acute respiratory infections.Options B and C: Kartagener syndrome is also known as primary ciliary dyskinesia/ immotile ciliasyndrome. It occurs due to a defect in the dynein arm of cilia. It is characterized by the triad of:• Sinusitis• Situs inversus• BronchiectasisOption D: In cystic fibrosis ciliary ultrastructure remains normal.

questions.question: What is the most common site of foregut cyst?
questions.explanation: Foregut cysts are most often located in the hilum or middle mediastinum.They are the congenital cysts that arise from abnormal detachments of primitive foregut. Foregutcysts are classified as bronchogenic, esophageal, or enteric. The most common type of foregut cystis bronchogenic cyst.Microscopically, the cyst is lined by ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reversible disorder?
questions.explanation: Contraction atelectasis is an irreversible disorder. It occurs when focal or generalized pulmonaryor pleural fibrosis prevents full lung expansion.1071Atelectasis refers either to an incomplete expansion of the lungs (neonatal atelectasis) or to thecollapse of the previously inflated lung.The main types of atelectasis in adults are:• Resorption atelectasis stems from complete obstruction of an airway. Over time, the air isresorbed from the dependent alveoli, which collapse. E.g. mucous plugs, foreign body aspiration• Compression atelectasis occurs whenever significant volumes of fluid, tumor, or air accumulatewithin the pleural cavity. E.g. pneumothorax, pleural effusion.• Contraction atelectasis occurs when focal or generalized pulmonary or pleural fibrosis preventsfull lung expansion.Completeobstructionof an airwayPleuralspaceMTypes of atelectasisResorptionHealthy lungHealthy lungSpace occupying lesion (loculated pleural effusion,elevated hemidiaphragm or solid chest mass of chest wall,pleura or parenchyma)MACompressionFocal or generalized pulmonary or pleural fibrosisprevents full lung expansion.ContractionOMARROWHealthy lung

questions.question: An infant born to a diabetic mother develops difficulty in breathing within 30 minutes ofbirth. Within a few hours, cyanosis becomes evident. Fine rales are heard over both lungfields. A chest x-ray film shows ground-glass picture. Which of the following is incorrectabout this condition?

options.A: It is associated with respiratory failure and poor prognosis despite treatment
options.B: There is deficiency of surfactant produced by type II alveolar cells
options.C: Increased corticosteroid release lower the risk of developing RDS
options.D: On microscopy, hyaline membranes with fibrin and necrotic cell debris are seen

questions.explanation: This clinical scenario is characteristic of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) or hyalinemembrane disease. With treatment, it rarely leads to respiratory failure and has a goodprognosis.The fundamental defect is a deficiency of pulmonary surfactant, produced by type IIpneumocytes.Microscopically, the hyaline membranes are largely made up of fibrin admixed with necrotic celldebris. Grossly, the lungs are of normal size, solid, airless, reddish-purple, and they usually sinkin water.Corticosteroids help in surfactant production and are given prophylactically to at-risk pregnantwomen.1072Lung surfactant actionMAlveoli without surfactantAlveoli with surfactantOMARROWWater moleculeCohesive forcebetween watermoleculesCollapsedalveolar wallSurfactant moleculeWater moleculeReduced forcebetween watermoleculesStable alveolar wall

questions.question: A newborn baby born at term was noted to have respiratory distress. Radiography revealed diffuse ground-glass opacities in all lung fields. Exogenous surfactant administration resulted in a brief improvement, but his condition continued to worsen once surfactant therapy was stopped. Which is the most common genetic mutation associated with this disorder?
questions.explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of surfactant dysfunction disorder. It is most commonly caused by mutations of the ABCA3 gene. In this disorder, lack of production of surfactant leads to severe respiratory failure in neonates. There is transient improvement with administration of exogenous surfactant, but it worsens once surfactant therapy is stopped. This condition occurs due to mutations in genes encoding proteins involved in surfactant trafficking or secretion, such as: • ATP binding cassette protein member 3 (ABCA3) • Surfactant protein C • Surfactant protein B

questions.question: A 76-year-old woman is brought to the casualty with high-grade fever, dysuria, and flankpain. On examination, she is disoriented with suprapubic and costovertebral angletenderness. Her BP is 70/40 mm Hg, pulse rate is 130/min, and her temperature is 103 ºF.She becomes increasingly hypoxic after admission and requires ventilation. What is the likelyreason for respiratory failure?
questions.explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of urosepsis. This presentation is likely the result of acuterespiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or shock lung. It is characterized histologically by diffusealveolar damage.It is also known as acute lung injury and is clinically characterized by the abrupt onset ofsignificant hypoxemia and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates in the absence of cardiac failure. Chestx-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates, known as white-out appearance. The prognosis is poorwith mortality up to 40%.1073Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)HyalinemembraneAlveolar edema withfibrin and epithelialcellsNeutrophils

questions.question: A 68-year-old man presented with episodes of shortness of breath and coughing at night thatawaken him from sleep. He was diagnosed with COPD 7 years ago. On examination,distended neck veins were observed and S3 was heard on auscultation. Bronchoalveolarlavage of this patient is given below. Identify the marked cells.1061
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of heart failure. The image shows heart failure cells, whichare siderophages or hemosiderin-containing macrophages.1074PulmonarycongestionHeart failure cellsHeart failure cellsHeartfailure cellsInflammatoryinfiltrateAlveolarwallThey are seen in the alveoli of patients with chronic pulmonary edema. The alveolar walls becomethickened and fibrosed. These pigmented macrophages result in a brown induration of the lung.The following image shows siderophages.1075Alveolar edemaCardiogenicleft ventricular heartfailure (LVHF)+pulmonary capillary wedge pressure↓Pulmonary oedema + haemorrhageCut section:Browninduration of thelung©MARROWNon cardiogenicARDSWMacrophagesengulfing RBCHeart Failure CellsHemosiderin laidenmacrophages

questions.question: A pathologist is examining the following histopathological section of an alveolus. All of thefollowing can be associated with this finding except:
questions.explanation: The given image shows diffuse alveolar damage which is the characteristic histologic finding ofacute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Heart failure is not associated with ARDS.1076Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)Alveolar edema withfibrin and epithelialcellsHyalinemembraneNeutrophilsARDS is characterized by bilateral pulmonary infiltrates and hypoxemia in the absence of heartfailure. The causes of ARDS are:•Sepsis• Diffuse pulmonary infections• Infectious viral, Mycoplasma, and Pneumocystis, miliary tuberculosis-• Gastric aspiration•Mechanical trauma, including head injuries, burns•Near-drowning

questions.question: Which of the following occurs in the stage of gray hepatization in pneumonia?

options.A: Accumulation of WBCs in the alveoli
options.B: Accumulation of RBCs in the alveoli
options.D: Accumulation of fibrin in the alveoli

questions.explanation: 1077In the stage of gray hepatization in pneumonia, there is an accumulation of fibrin along withdisintegration of RBCs within the alveoli.Bacterial pneumonias can be classified morphologically as:• Lobular pneumonia (bronchopneumonia) - patchy consolidation of the lung• Lobar pneumonia consolidation of an entire lobeStages of lobar pneumonia are as follows:StagesDuratiDescriptiononCongestionRed hepatizatio1-2 dayS2-4 danysGray hepatizati4-8 daonysRBCs andexudatefluid in thealveoliAccumulation ofneutrophils,RBCsandfibrinin the alveoliThe disintegration of RBCs with thepersistenceoffibrinosuppurativeexudateResolution9-10 daysMost common outcome

questions.question: Which of the following is not seen in patients with viral pneumonia?

options.D: Multinucleate giant cells in the bronchiolar wall

questions.explanation: The predominance of alveolar exudates is a feature of bacterial pneumonia, not viral pneumonia.

questions.question: A 65-year-old HIV-positive man presented with fever and breathlessness for 2 weeks. Imagingshows dense infiltration in the lower lobe and the lung biopsy showed the following finding.What is the diagnosis?1063
questions.explanation: The given image shows a cytomegalic pneumocyte containing characteristic intranuclearbasophilic inclusion surrounded by a clear halo known as owl's eye appearance. Along with thegiven clinical scenario, it is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) pneumonia.1078CMV Pneumonia - Lung BiopsyOwl's eyeappearanceCMV is a-group herpesvirus. It causes the following conditions:• Immunocompetent individuals asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like infection--• Neonates devastating systemic infections• Immunosuppressed individuals - serious, life-threatening, disseminated CMV infections of thelungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (colitis)Option A: Small-cell carcinoma has small cells with scant cytoplasm, salt-and-pepper chromatinwith inconspicuous nucleoli.Option C: In cryptococcal infection, encapsulated yeasts are seen on direct microscopy.Option D: Tuberculosis is associated with well-defined epithelioid granuloma.1079

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman underwent an emergency LSCS under general anesthesia to deliver aterm, healthy infant. Two hours later, she developed sudden tachypnea, cyanosis, andmassive pulmonary edema and died despite resuscitative measures. The histopathologicalpicture of her lung is shown below. What is the likely cause of death?1064

options.B: Cryptogenic organizing pneumoniaCMV pneumoniad) Pneumocystis carinii pneumoniaQuestion 16:A 35-year-old depressed man came with complaints of sudden onset breathlessness, withdesaturation. Chest x-ray showed bilateral diffuse infiltrates with predominant involvementof right middle and lower lobes. The patient could not be revived despite treatment. Onautopsy, the lungs appeared grossly normal. The histopathology image of the lung is as shownbelow. Which among the following is the appropriate cause?a) Necrotizing TB granulomab) Vegetative matter aspiration pneumonia

questions.explanation: The given scenario and image showing massive neutrophilic infiltration are suggestiveof Mendelson's syndrome or aspiration pneumonitis.Mendelson's syndrome is a chemical pneumonitis caused by the aspiration of sterile gastriccontents during general anesthesia, especially during pregnancy. The most common cause ofmaternal mortality associated with general anesthesia is either due to a pulmonary aspiration or afailed endotracheal intubation.The risk factors for Mendelson's syndrome include:• Gastric volume > 25 mL (0.4 mL/kg)• Gastric pH < 2.5Incidence of aspiration can be reduced by administration of:• Non-particulate antacids like sodium citrate 30-45 minutes prior to intubation• H2 receptor antagonists like intravenous ranitidine• Metoclopramide 1-2 hours prior to inductionOption B: Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia is a type of ILD associated with Masson bodies andplugs of loose connective tissue on histology.Option C: CMV pneumonia is associated with the owl's eye appearance on histology.Option D: PCP pneumonia is associated with black-walled cysts on silver staining.

questions.question: A 25-year-old man presented with fever, productive cough, and breathlessness of 2 months' duration. CECT chest revealed bilateral upper lobe fibrotic lesions and enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes. Lymph node biopsy revealed the following. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given image shows the presence of granulomas of epithelioid cells with central caseous necrosis and Langhan's giant cells. These findings point towards the diagnosis of tuberculosis. Langhan's giant cells show horseshoe or slipper-shaped arrangements of nuclei. Tuberculosis Langhans giant cell caseous necrosis

questions.question: A 38-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to several weeks of occasionalhemoptysis, weight loss, and fever. He has lost 7 kg over the past 3 months. Sputum culturegrows acid-fast bacilli and his chest X-ray is shown below. What is this lesion called?
questions.explanation: The given x-ray of this patient with tuberculosis shows an infraclavicular lesion. It is known asAssmann's focus.1081Primary tuberculosis occurs on first exposure and involves lower part of upper lobe andpart of lower lobe. The following findings may be seen:• Ghon's focus focus of infection located subpleurally-• Ghon's complex - Ghon's focus with lymph node involvement• Ranke complex - a calcified Ghon's complexupperSecondary tuberculosis occurs due to the reactivation of TB. It affects the apex. The followingfindings may be seen:• Puhl's complex - supraclavicular lesion• Assmann's complex - infraclavicular lesionDisseminated or miliary tuberculosis is characterised by 1-2 mm disseminated lesions all over thelung. The following findings may be associated:• Simon's focus - early hematogenous seeding in the apex of lungs• Rich focus tuberculous caseous foci in brain, meninges and spinal cord-

questions.question: A 61-year-old man presented with fever, night sweats, and weight loss. The patientsubsequently died a few weeks later. Gross specimen of the lung is shown below. Which of thefollowing is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and the gross image showing individual lesions which are small(2-mm) foci of yellow-white consolidation scattered through the lung parenchyma is suggestiveof miliary tuberculosis.Miliary tuberculosis (TB) refers to the widespread dissemination ofMycobacterium tuberculosis via hematogenous spread. It occurs when organisms drainingthrough the lymphatics enter the venous blood and circulate back to the lung. Miliary TB mayinfect any number of organs, including the lungs, liver, and spleen.The adjective 'miliary' is derived from the resemblance of these foci to millet seeds. Mantoux testis negative in miliary TB.

questions.question: A 48-year-old patient with a history of IV drug abuse had presented to the casualty withshortness of breath and fever with chills. Clinical examination had revealed markedhepatosplenomegaly and diffuse rales in all lung fields. His spot HIV test was positive. Theadmission chest X-ray and a repeat X-ray taken 3 days later are shown below. The patientdied a few hours after the 2nd X-ray was taken. Which of the following statements regardinghis diagnosis is true?1067

options.A: The cause of death likely a malignant pleural effusion
options.B: The spread is mostly due to lymphatic disseminationPancytopenia may be seen due to infiltration of the bone marrowd) It is a form of disseminated extrapulmonary tuberculosisPORTET/OGQuestion 21:A 52-year-old woman diagnosed with COVID-19 developed severe shortness of breath anddied 5 days after admission. What lung pathology can be expected in this patient on autopsy?a) Fibrin thrombi in capillariesb) Diffuse alveolar damage

questions.explanation: The given history, clinical features, and chest X-Ray point towards a diagnosis of miliarytuberculosis. Pancytopenia may be seen due to infiltration of the bone marrow in such cases.The second X-ray shows acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Chest x-ray appearance ofARDS varies depending on the severity and typically appears as bilateral diffuse alveolaropacities with dependent atelectasis in some cases. The opacities may have a patchy ground-glassappearance. The cause of death here is likely ARDS. (option A)In immunodeficient individuals (eg.- patient having HIV), there may occur widespreaddissemination of M. tuberculosis, via the hematogenous route (option B) that leads to the seedingof bacteria in various organs (hepatosplenomegaly). This is known as miliary TB.It is a form of disseminated pulmonary tuberculosis, and not extrapulmonary (option D)1082The risk factors of miliary TB include-• Extremes of age• Alcohol use••Malignancy• HIV• Corticosteroids• Connective tissue disease• Renal failure• Diabetes, and pregnancy
